item.description: An expandable hex and counter wargame where terrain plays a huge factor in the actions and reactions of the units.

name.value: English Soccer Manager: Two Page Wars

item.description: Pick one of eight fictional teams in England and lead them to a victorious football season. Using two pages, one for counters and one for a map you will have to attempt to manage your team in the most effective manner while keeping an eye on your cash flows.

Air traffic controller is a logic based game in which you must manage an airport. Each turn you can make one command to an aircraft. Each aircraft then follows that command until another one is issued. Throughout the game new aircraft are taking off or landing, so managing the space on the tarmac is extremely important.

item.description: Economic gears is a game based in a fantasy world which is used to teach and learn about economic functions in society. During each turn players are allowed to place new tiles to grow the allowed economic area of the game. Furthermore each player takes part in the economic success of the new nation by building up a transportation empire to move the newly discovered goods.

In an alternate Europe six nations compete to gain the upper hand in economic and military power. Using a territory movement system, and an in depth economic guide players attempt to compete with the other six players while finishing the goals given to them. (Game also includes an expansion which adds North America into the mix!)
A fantasy based wargame in which two nations go to war. One comes from the desert with fast horsemen, while the other is entangled in a civil war while attempting to fight off the enemy.
On a round board, try to move 5 balls to the center of the labyrinth, without let any of them fall from the border.

A new concept in word games with the great advantage of involving all the players in the fun of the game all of the time. The game can be played by the whole family & by any number of players.

The game centres around the planners or plans. These are the 'Crosswords' made up by all the players before the play actually begins. These planners are filled out by each player in crossword fashion on a particular theme or subject eg. Film Stars, The Sea, Sport etc & the rest of the players have to find the words in these plans - the player with the most points being the winner.

A game concept that can grow & even use tiles from other word games !

From the editor:
Camillo and his 11 friends love parties and are keen to take part in whatever is going on.

But they never come without invitation: the coloured faces on the spinning top show which friend may come. But watch out: some symbols on the top bring unexpected surprises with them, making the game exciting to the very end! Let Camillo and his friends bring a real party mood into your playroom.

Players race, using the shortest routes possible, through more than 100 cities of The Netherlands and adjacent areas in Germany and France. The first player to return to his starting point wins the game.

Contents (1985 edition):

1 board, 1 six-sided die, 6 flags, 6 pawns, 74 place cards, 55 numbered cards for places with attractions, 18 luck cards, 3 reserve cards, rules with information on the 55 tourist attractions

item.description:
A football (soccer) board game produced and published by Ravensburger Germany just before the World Cup 2006. Each player has only one pawn (pl. piece) and 3 six-sided dice. The dice are used to move the pl. piece, but:

 The first die has this value 1,2,2,3,3,4
 The second 1,2,3,4,5,fault
 The third 2,4,6,6,fault,fault -> (long running but 33% of chances to get the fault side of the die)




Who scores first 3 goals is the winner...

The board of the game is like a football stadium, with some lines and holes for the pl.pieces movements.

A simple cardgame by Bruno Faidutti, totally based on bluff. Players try to move their 5 treasures in one of their ships, but only two of their five ships can be armed with cannons. Who can bluff their way across the oceans while opponents try to send pirates to attack unprotected ships?

item.description:
Subbuteo Free Kick is a football (soccer game). It focuses on set pieces. The attacking player flicks his Player to chip the ball into the goal using a ramp. The defending player positions a three man wall and operates the goalkeeper on a stick to defend the free kick. The first to five goals wins.

A self contained game, it is designed to encourage younger players to build their skills ready for the full Subbuteo game. Promotional version available in conjunction with Nestle Yorkie.

name.value: Political Capital: The Economist board game

item.description:
A pull-out game from the Christmas 1998 issue of The Economist magazine.

Each player represents the leader of a country. Every leader wants to stay in power for longer than any of his peers--that's what it takes to win. To achieve this you need to manage your political-capital points. The to and fro of normal political life will eat into your capital--but good judgment, good luck and well timed elections can replenish it.

Pola Naftowe is a Polish game about building and running oil companies. The players build their oil empires by buying oil-tankers, oil wells and refineries. The main game mechanism is auction - players sell oil in the two sessions of stock-market. The game lasts for five rounds, player with the biggest amount of money at the end is the winner.

item.description:
A Monopoly-style game from Late For The Sky publishing which uses a thematic setting of Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

Summer Fest and The Great Circus Parade are the utilities in this game, and property cards cover places like the Bradley Center, County Stadium, Miller and Pabst Brewing Companies, Harley-Davidson, Usinger's Sausage, the Pfeister Hotel, and the Allen-Bradley Clock Tower.

The tokens which are unique to this edition are a pewter mug of beer with a frosty head on it, a pretzel, a baseball glove, a snowman, a sailboat, and one other item (not sure about which one it was)...

Peruse Water Street, sail in Lake Michigan, visit the zoo, or BOWL! All centered around a nice graphic of the tower of Milwaukee's historic City Hall.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
For 3-4 players

Background : This game is not meant to be historical by nature. Instead it is a very rough sketch into political maneuvering and backstabbing used to get people into high positions of power. Since it is not historical, in the process of designing no real names were used. Even though some cards have images on them of famous people, they do not mean or correspond to anything (instead they are merely a card.)

Goal : At the end of the game who ever has the MOST of their color at the front of the line wins the game.

A game about the Battle of Vimeiro. Included are the counters and maps you will need to play the game. This is part of the Historical Series of free war-games for paperworlds.com (Now defunct). Overall this is an abstract look at the battle fought between the British and French in Portugal.
A small and light game about elite units who forcefully retake space ships from pirates. Game is on a level of individual combat.

name.value: Wicked Narrows: Rome's Disaster at Kalkreis, Sept 9, 2 A.D.

item.description:
Wicked Narrows covers the Roman disaster in the Teutoburg Forest on September 9th, 2 A.D. Led by one of Rome’s favorite son’s, German born Arminius, turned on those that loved and trained him, leading four German tribes (18000 men) into deadly battle with Varus’ Roman Army. The German ambush at the Kalkriese Narrows ( a narrow strip of land only 220m wide) caught the Romans by complete surprise with an am-bush. One the 2nd day, all 20000 Romans had been killed. This game focuses on the second day as the Romans approached the narrows and the German attack !

The map scale is about 550 yards per hex. Each combat unit is a cohort of 500 men for the Roman and between 500-1000 men for the German. A game turn represents one hour of time.

The design is unique and captures the flavor of battle during this period. The game depends upon the German player and when he launches his devastating attack. In fact, until the German attacks, the Romans simply casually march towards their destination. When the attacks begin, blood will spill across the map as the Romans try desperately try to maintain damage control. But this is hard, as the German tribes create an attack like a shark frenzy, which only continues to become more barbaric!

The battle sequence contains three rounds of types of combat, leaders and morale are vital and is impacted by what happens in the combat rounds.

One 11x17 Map, rules, 280 counters. Still only $16.00. Designed by Kerala Cironi. Developed by Perry Moore.

Royal Battles is a strategic board game of small scale battles played with playing cards and chess pieces. In Royal Battles players compete to defeat each other in head-to-head combat. Each player builds an army of 4 units (represented with chess pieces) and maneuvers them on a battle board made from a tile grid of playing cards. Each unit has a special ability that sets it apart and it is the combination of units and abilities that will determine the difference between victory and defeat.

Requires playing cards (standard poker or bridge decks) and chess pieces.

Roll the special Letter Roll dice and flip over the timer. Players race to list words containing the three letters shown on the dice. Only words listed by a single player score points, so players are rewarded for both their speed and creative thinking.

Components

Seven polyhedral dice (20-sided?). 
The color of the dice indicate how frequently their letters appear in English:
 2 white dice – frequently used letters
 3 blue dice – less frequently used letters
 2 orange dice – infrequently used letters
1 two-Minute timer for the standard game
1 one-Minute Timer for the fast-play game
Four pads and four pencils

Gameplay

Decide whether to use the short or long timer. One player chooses 4 of the 7 dice and rolls them. The player to their left removes a die of their choice. Players then write down all words they can think of which contain the remaining 3 letters and any number of other letters. When time is up, word lists are read and you must cross out any word which someone else has used. Your remaining unique words are your points. All 7 dice are then passed to the next player and the process is repeated. Each person rolls 1 to 3 times, depending on the number of players, at which point whoever has the most points wins.

For younger players use fewer and easier dice; for expert players use 4 dice instead of 3 and set a limit on the minimum number of letters that a word must contain.

Note: before starting, players may want to decide whether to change the rule that allows repeating the same root word. For example, if played as written, cheat, cheats, cheated, cheating, cheater are all allowed.

From the Rules book:

The Shepherdess, her sheep and dog must return under cover in the sheepfold before the wind takes away the bridge.
Will the players manage to cooperate in taking all the sheep back to the sheepfold

La bergère, ses moutons et son chien doivent rentrer à l'abri dans la bergerie avant que le vent n'emporte le pont.
Les joueurs parviendron-ils à coopérer pour ramener tous les moutons à la bergerie ?

Die Schafhirtin, ihre Schafe und ihr Hütehund müssen in den schützenden Schafsstall gelangen, bevor der Wind die Brücke mitnimmt.
Shaffen es die Spieler zusammenzuarbeiten, um alle Schafe in den Schfstall zu bringen ?
 La pastora, sus ovejas y su perro tienen que volver a refugiarse al refugio antes de que el viento sa lleve el puente por los aires.
Podràn cooperar los jugadores para llevar a todas las ovelas de vuelta al refugio ?

Ages 4 and up.

item.description:
Long ago on a small island lived a tribe with a problem. For as long as they could remember each member of the tribe had been infected with the dreaded toe-sap fungus. With every step taken, a small droplet of toe-sap would ooze from each toe. This, of course, was a constant source of shame to the tribe members.

Then one day a young man named Johnny discovered two important facts that would change the island forever -- the toe-sap was actually quite delicious and each tribe member produced a different flavor. Johnny was hailed as a hero and soon toe-sap became the island's number one export.

Tribe members spent long days gathering toe-sap, however it soon became apparent that the tribal leaders could influence the toe-sap market, making some varieties more valuable.

As members of the tribe, players take turns collecting varieties of toe-sap. They can also offer cows to the tiny sea-going Cownivores in order to collect toe-sap more quickly. At the end of the game, the players influence the tribal leaders using shells and their remaining cows to dictate the price of each variety of toe-sap.

Dust is a strategy board game of conquest and control. Seize power sources and capitals, develop your infrastructure, and build and wield vast, high-tech armies in your bid for global domination.

Players will probably recognize the map as that of Earth, but what they will not see are any borders or nations. In the world of Dust, the unending war and the new technologies have altered the political face of Earth beyond all recognition.

At the beginning of each turn, players select a card from their hand. This card represents their strategy for the coming turn and to a large extent dictates the actions a player can take.

During their production phase, players spend production points to buy additional factories and units. Each individual unit type has its own unique statistics and effects, so players have to carefully consider the composition of their armies.

In combat, players alternate rolling dice and destroying units until one side has been eliminated (either due to casualties or retreats) or a cease-fire is declared.

At the end of each game round, players score victory points for power sources, capitals, and majorities they control. The player who controls the most land areas earns bonus victory points, as does the player who controls the most sea areas and the player who controls the most production centers. The first player to amass a set number of victory points while also controlling a capital is the winner.

Only once a player has amassed at least half the victory points required to win can he or she attack an enemy capital. Once the war has been so escalated, however, then all players are free to attack capitals.

Dust English Rules Premium Version http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg_content/Dust/Dust_Rulebook_Prem_Eng.pdf
Dust English Rules Epic Version http://www.fantasyflightgames.com/ffg_content/Dust/Dust_Rulebook_Epic_Enig.pdf
Backstage http://www.kaleidosgames.com

item.description: A soccer game that uses dice to move the ball up and down the field as well as to determine whether a goal is scored.

In this game, players try to make as much money as possible by buying and selling stock. The companies you can buy stock in are actual Swedish companies. Things get shaken up by Unforeseen Event-cards, as well as taxation and meddling from the minister of economics and the minister of budgets. Another unusual feature is that you can take a loan, that last for 15 real-world minutes.

item.description: In this game, the player take on the roles as "raggare" (Swedish fans of beautiful women and American 50's youth culture) and try to get their chosen "pök" (chick) to the gravel pit to do burnout in their "fårrd" (Ford). To do this, they have to collect essential raggar-paraphernalia like sideburns and Brylcreem, all the while avoiding the police cruiser and the slow moving Volvo. The game is based on Byhåla, a popular Swedish TV-show from the early '90s.

Simple dice game simulating a hole of golf.
A player first rolls the green die to try to get on the green (2 out of 6 chances). Once on the green the player rolls the white die until he sinks the ball (2 in 6 chance). 
On the first roll of the green die only, the player has a 1 in 6 chance of hitting a hole in one.

The game comes with a sand timer, which is not used for the main game as described above - players just try to roll certain outcomes on the die as many times as they can in a fixed time.

Other games in this series - Tennis, Soccer and Cricket

Simple dice game simulating a tennis match.
The serving player uses the white die and the receiving player uses the green die. Players take turns rolling their die until a point is scored either way.

Two kinds of matches can be played: either play for the best of six games, or each player tries to score as many points as possible in a fixed time (using the timer).

Other games in this series - Golf, Soccer and Cricket

Simple dice game simulating a soccer match.
Two dice, a timer, counters, score pad and a pencil are provided.
Other games in this series - Golf, Tennis and Cricket

Simple dice game simulating a cricket match.
The game comes with two dice, a sand timer, counters, a pencil and a score pad.
Other games in the series: Golf, Tennis and Soccer

Since Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay first climbed Mount Everest in 1953, many mountaineers have attempted to repeat their exploit, but with great difficulty.

In this game, YOU are responsible for a team of mountaineers whose objective is to reach the summit of Everest. You will establish one of the supply camps essential to your climbs. You will manage and move human and material resources while facing many dangers in the mountain.

Beware, a strange creature wanders in these sacred regions. The yeti is no longer a legend...

Embark on this great adventure where the courage of your team-mates will make all the difference.

On your mark, get set, ...go!

FROM White Wolf's website:

The Empire Could Be Yours!

In a vast, fantastic world known as Creation, a dynastic empire called the Realm stood for hundreds of years, presided over by the powerful and cunning Scarlet Empress. She reigned with an absolute hand until the day she mysteriously disappeared, leaving a legacy of ruin. Before long, suitors to the throne dared make their bid for power. You are one of the contenders for the Scarlet Throne, a Dragon-Blooded who has amassed the vast armies, fortunes and magic necessary to seize your destiny. You seek to claim dominions and raise war manses, building power until you have the lore and strength to claim the Imperial Manse for your own.

Exalted: War for the Throne is a strategy board game for two to five players set in the world of Exalted®. Players amass legions, coin and essence, and bring all of their allies, will and luck to bear to claim the seat of power and become the new emperor of the Realm.

This game includes:

• A fold-out board with a map of the Blessed Isle, the battleground for the throne

• 5 different aspects from which to choose, all with their own playing pieces and unique powers

• 50 Events Cards and 25 Charm Cards with which to attack, deceive and stymie opponents

• All the dice you need to play

ISBN: 978-1-58846-542-9

link.value: From RPG books to board games

item.description:
Party Pooper is the spontaneous party game that will have players pointing in all directions to discover who’s the party pooper and who’s the party animal.

One player rolls the die, which tells if they will be selecting a "party pooper" (person least likely to) or "party animal" (person most likely to). They then read a card containing one of the 432 hypothetical scenarios (such as "a friend suspects her husband of cheating on her and wants you to follow him and take pictures"). Each other player then decides whom they think the reader will choose as most/least likely to do such a thing. The reader says "1-2-3-Choose" and everyone points their finger at someone (you can choose yourself, if you wish). If you choose the person the reader chose, you get a chip. The reader gets a chip for each player who chooses the person they picked. After everyone has been the reader 2 or 3 times (depending on the number of players), the game is over and whoever has the most chips wins.

A game similar in play to Perfection, but with a 3D Cars theme.

From the back of the box: "Race to put Mater back together. But don't just 'tool around.' -- You have to be fast to beat the clock. Because when his parts fly, it's time to say goodbye. Later Mater!"

In "The Junk Yard", players (solo or with a partner or even in teams) attempt to knock down targets with a steel ball, propelled by flippers. Rubber bands provide the tension for the flippers and drop targets (tin cans, boots, etc). 
It is a simple dexterity game, but can provide many hours of fun. The "Keep Out" targets cause you to lose the ball, and the targets have various point amounts, with the center 500 targets being easy to drain down the middle.

Players/Teams can compete to get the highest score.

"It's Grandma Edna's birthday and she longs for her favorite, apple pie. The family gets up early in order to gather all the ingredients from around the farm; apples have to be picked, the grain ground and the cow milked. Everybody is in a hurry as they all want to be the first to surprise Grandma Edna with their apple pie.

Who will, with a bit of luck and a good overview, be the quickest to collect all the ingredients?"

This game may be played cooperatively or competitively. Players choose a final food (pie, sandwich, etc) and must assemble the ingredients from around the farm. Some items are one step, such as gathering apples, some are multi-step such as feeding hay to the cow to obtain milk which is then processed into cheese.

Bonus advanced instructions for including cow patties into the equation, possibly a gaming first!

item.description:
This is an educational game, endorsed by the Rottnest Island Authority and (heavily) sponsored by Agfa Film. It's a standard Roll and Move game with a single path and a start and end. The first half of the path is by boat from the mainland to the island, the second half is by bike on the island itself. The main theme, not surprising given the sponsorship, is photographing wildlife.

As usual with these sorts of games, various points along the path cause things to happen, mostly drawing a card of some sort. You win by getting a photograph of a quokka and getting to the end of the path. There are a group of six quokka photo squares, such that you can't possibly miss it on the way through.

The main educational content of the game is a small brochure with (tourist) information about the island.

From the bottom of the box:

Don't let your "eyes be conned"!

Match the most "icon" tiles by removing them from the tray in 60 seconds...and win!

Each player takes turns matching the tiles. Set the 60-second timer and GO! Pull exact matching tiles from the specially designed box tray using your "magic" suction wand as fast as you can. But be careful--only exact matches count!

Players count their tiles--the most matches win.

EYE-CONS is also designed for solitaire or team play, and is always great for the whole family.

name.value: Elections The Race to the White House

item.description:
The object of the game is to have the most electoral votes. The game ends when the players have won all the states.

Players start with a random home state and four cards, each of which represents a random number of votes. Each player also has two pawns, one starts on the assigned home state; the other on the “Campaign Starts” space on the track. In turn, a player rolls two dice and advances one’s pawn counterclockwise around the track. The space on which a player lands may award the player vote cards, call for a chance card, allow a TV debate (giving a opportunity to steal an opponent's state) or call for an election. When an election is called for, the player moves one’s own pawn to an adjacent state. The players declare how many vote cards each will commit to the election. All the votes are revealed and the player, who committed the most votes without exceeding the state’s limit, as printed on the gameboard, is awarded the state and its electoral votes.

Deep within the orcish caverns, the drums begin to beat. High in the treetops, the watch sounds the horns of the hunt. The Clans are on the move, the ancient war begins anew. The Elven Champions gather, test their weapons, draw up their resolve.

Under the earth, the Orcish King rails against the Elves, exhorting his troops to blood-frenzy. The Queen of the Elves bids her heroes to her, impresses upon them the nature of their task. Tonight the battle will rage. A thousand Orcs will come to slaughter, and a handful of Elves will return the favor.

HeroCard OrcWars is an asymmetrical fantasy game of fierce combat for two players. OrcWars comes as a two player game with the Paladin and Orc King hero decks. It can be expanded to four players with additional HeroCard decks and figures.

HeroCard OrcWars is expanded by:


 HeroCard Orc Wars Ranger Expansion Deck
 HeroCard Orc Wars Sorceress Expansion Deck

link.value: HeroCard Orc Wars: Ranger Expansion Deck
HeroCard Orc Wars: Sorceress Expansion Deck

item.description:
A fan created free to print CCG based on Dr Who (not related in anyway to the Doctor Who Collectible Card Game published by M.M.G. Ltd.)

From the website:
In the spirit of Who, the villains (Enemies) attempt to reach Goals played on Spacetime cards to score points. Meanwhile, the Doctor and his Allies try to stop them and score those points first. Each player plays both his own TARDIS crew and the Enemies their opponent’s TARDIS will face. First player to 10 points (and Reaching and Opposing at least one Goal) wins.

A public domain adaptation of Havoc: The Hundred Years War using a regular deck of cards.

Aside from differences in number (players are dealt 5 cards, only 2 cards are placed as "recruits", etc.) and cosmetic differences (2s are used in place of "Dogs", Jokers as pairs of Dogs, etc.) the significant differences is the use of the face up recruit cards and a randomly drawn card to determine the point value of each battle at the moment it is called. This changes the game considerably as it eliminates the role of strategy about future battles, which is an important element of Havoc.

This is a simple roll and move style game based on the British waterways of the 19th Century.

Players must negotiate a series of canals to get to the wharf, collect coal and return to the Paper mill.

Players take it in turn to take cards from a pile and move the number of spaces shown on the card. Some cards give specific bonuses like extra movement.

Also included are the rules for a more complex version of the game called Boatman's Bluff. This uses the same components but adds a bit more strategy to the game.

It was published in association with the British Waterways Board

In this game, you begin in the middle of the ocean and navigate shark-infested waters! You become an explorer and a pirate as you overcome formidable adversaries in your quest to reach the awe-inspiring volcano, the cozy igloo in the far North, the idyllic tropical beach and the thrilling amusement park. The hero of this great adventure is the first player to land a game piece on each of the four dream destinations in cold, mild, and hot climates utilizing dice rolls combining plus [warm] and minus [cool] symbols as well as number rolls.

This is simply the Turkish version of Monopoly. It is essentially the same as the standard Monopoly game and other variations, but in Turkish with the properties all being places in Istanbul. In the current version, two of the railroads are replaced with ferry terminals. The chance and community chest cards are apparently based on the British version and thus lack pictures aside from an arrow for advancing to Go and bars for going to jail. They also differ slightly from the modern American cards and are closer to the older American version.

Jackson's Foot Cavalry

The game will a block game with point to point movement covering Stonewall Jackson's classic 1862 Valley Campaign. The game system will be using our Forged in Fire rules with adjustments for the situation facing both Union and Confederate commanders in the Shenandoah Valley. Supply and surprise will be critical as Jackson races up and down the Valley fighting one Union force after another as the Union try to trap the Confederates. The game will include a main campaign as well as several shorter scenarios. Playable in 3-4 hours for the full campaign with 1-2 hours for scenarios. Victory is determined by how many Union troops the Confederate player can force the Union player to keep in the Valley. The Union player will try to keep the bare minimum of troops in the Valley to prevent the Confederate player from obtaining certain objectives.

According to Worthington's June 1, 2011 update this game will be the first in a series including games on the Vicksburg, Gettysburg, Overland, and Atlanta campaigns as well as an update of Forged in Fire: The 1862 Peninsula Campaign.

The game plays similarly to games like Balderdash in which players make up a meaning to a phrase and everybody votes on which they think is the real phrase. In this game, however, players are trying to guess the correct description to the scientific name of a plant or animal.

The game contains 968 plants & animals on 242 cards.

The Djungle deck has 11 cards with funny animals on them in 4 different colours, giving a total of 44 cards.

The players collect points during 4 rounds, but each round uses different rules:

- 1st round: after a card is drawn, a player must try to imitate that animal's voice to collect points
- 2nd round: the rules are adapted from "Pit", but played with this deck of cards
- 3rd round: the rules are taken from "Hearts"
- 4th round: the rules are taken from "Uno"

The player with the most points after 4 rounds is the winner.

name.value: Maya & Miguel Piñata Party Card Game

item.description:
It's Piñata Party time!

Join Maya & Miguel for this fast-paced card game. Uno, dos, tres! play your cards quickly and in sequence until all of them are used, or until someone shouts, "La Piñata!" Ages 6 and up

Skills: Reading Required

Katamino Duo – a.k.a., Katamini – is a junior version of Katamino, with two players competing on separate game boards (or possibly one game board divided into smaller spaces) to fill all of the empty spaces first. The game is played over a number of rounds, with each round becoming progressively harder.

Katamino Duo also works as a solitaire puzzle, with the solver trying to fit the pieces onto the playing area in different ways.

item.description:
Lingo is a 5 or 6 letter word guess game. The first letter is given. A little like Mastermind, after a word is given, the correct letters are marked. A different mark is given for letters on the correct position.

Each correct word will given you numbers, which you can then remove from you bingo-card. The first to have a line with 5 crosses on its bingo-card wins the game.

Note: This game is based on a Dutch TV-show.

A Jr. version of Tumblin-Dice. This game uses 2 sets dice instead of 4. The board is smaller and has only two 4X areas instead of three.

A dexterity dice game consisting of two sets of colored dice one either slides, rolls, or flicks down a stepped surface. Usually one slides the die for better accuracy. After each person has slid their 4 dice, points are scored. You score the die roll times either 1X, 2X, 3X, or 4X depending on which area of the board the die is on. (Dice which land in the 0X region are immediately removed from play.) High scoring rolls are targets for opponents. Four rounds are played and the player with the most points win.

item.description:
Tip simulates the well known Soccer-Toto sweepstakes. Instead of 12 real soccer games, 12 rounds of Tip card game are played.

There are 96 cards in total: 
- 28 x "1" (7 cards in red, yellow, blue and green)
- 28 x "X" (7 cards in red, yellow, blue and green)
- 28 x "2" (7 cards in red, yellow, blue and green)
- 7 x "V", black/dark yellow coloured
- 4 x "Combi", each with 3 of the 4 colours above
- 1 x "Trick" with all 4 colors

Each player plays is dealt 10 cards and then secretly writes down his tip (1, x or 2). During play, each player tries to collect a winning hand, which consists of 1 set of 4 and 2 sets of 3 cards.

Points can be won for having the winning hand as well as for having marked the correct tip.

At the end of the 12 rounds, the total number of correct tips are summarized and a last payout of points takes place. 
The player with the most points is the winner of the game.

This matching game is based on the popular I Spy series of books. The game includes four boards filled with pictures of various objects. A deck of thirty cards includes one matching card for each of those objects. Each turn, a card is turned over. The first player to find the matching object on the boards wins that round. The first to get six matching cards wins.

Each year for the past ten years, purple clouds would appear, and bring disasters to people around the world.
When their village is attacked again Shu, Kluke, and Jiro fight back against the fin that appears to kill the people. However, they discover it is a strange machine. But even after damaging it, it goes back to the flagship, with the three still on it.
There, they encounter constant attacks from metal soldiers until they discover three orbs of light. After hearing a voice tell them to swallow the orbs, they do and discover their shadows grow into monsters; Kluke's becomes a blue phoenix, Jiro's a blue minotaur, and Shu's a blue dragon. They then fight the ship's captain, Nene, and discover that Nene is behind the yearly attacks on their town. He easily defeats them, and they can barely make it to an escape capsule. They then land far from home and must then journey to find a way to save their land.
Following their escape from Nene's air fortress, they encounter more people from towns that have also fallen victim to the purple clouds, and decide that they must try to stop Nene from continuing to bring ruin on their world.

This is a CCG currently with 2 volumes (sets) that plays out in this world...

name.value: City Game: El Juego de las 20 Ciudades Olímpicas

item.description:
City Game, is a game similar to Trivial Pursuit where players must to choose the correct answer among three in the race to conquer the cities of the world that celebrated the Olympic Games in the past, the fist is Athens in 1896 the last is Atlanta in 1996

The questions are based in typical things of each city,and players roll a die and move along the world to complete all cities. First player to complete all win the game.

The game is in Spanish and the components are:
- 1 big game board of the world
- 1000 cards question-answers
- 10 counters
- 3 dices, one of numbers and two specials with a letter to correspond a part of an area of the world
- 1 rulebook

Award winning introductory form of checkers with a smaller 6x6 board covered with instructions to help children remember the set-up and legal plays. Included in the packaging is a foldout pictorial list of easy lessons and alternate rules to make the game intriguing and interesting for the growing player. The board is double-sided and has a regular (though still labeled) 8x8 board on the reverse.

Okey is a traditional Turkish game, similar to Rummikub.

Players manage their hand to make runs and sets. The first one to use all his pieces wins the game.

The game needs paying careful attention on the opponent's discarded pieces and plan the new series according to them, as there is only a pair of every piece.

link.value: Card Games: Draw and Discard Games

item.description:
Brocante is a interesting trade game, with a significant bit of luck, but also an important tactical element.

The players earn money while playing the lottery, and by reselling the objects which they accrue. The easy way is in the price of the objects. In each type, there are four prices. Most expensive is to be sold first. The prices are 3500, 2500, 1500 and 1000. Players collect the eight objects in a set, without doubles.

Players try to buy the objects that would complete other players' sets, especially to double the price when selling to the player who needs the object (and reap greater profits).

But, while objects are purchased from most-to-least expensive, they are sold least-to-most expensive.

The players move figures representing Holmes and Watson around a board representing London trying to uncover 6 clue cards relating to a specific mystery before their opponents. There are no dice or spinners, just tactical movements based on deduction and skill.

A game based on a TV quiz show that challenges your perceptions of stereotypes !

Over 2,200 questions across 52 categories. Questions & teasers to occupy the most active of minds & challenge the cleverest of clogs. Whether with your family or with friends, play at home & experience the excitement & challenge of the TV show.

Will you be revealed as the Brainiest ?

The object of the game is to position your own dice in a row next to each other. The dice must be in a straight line, not around a corner. They may be in any numerical order.

A simple dice strategy game for all ages.

The quest for the "Ultimate Dungeon Crawl" is over.

"Treasure Quest" is here...

An adaption of WOTC's D20 D&D system, D&D Mini's game and inspired by adventure board and video games, past and present, Treasure Quest takes player-heroes into the depths of treasure-rich and monster-ridden dungeons. The goal is to get in, get the treasure, and get out. 
Alive.

Using your own grid/hex based maps/ boards, D&D miniatures and scenary, Treasure Quest is a streamlined set of rules for adventuring, combat, dungeon exploration, and treasure/experience collection with or without a DM.

Version 5.0 featuring new streamlined mechanics, solo play options and a more comprehensive rules guide is now available as a free download.

Taken from the ASG description: Yggdrasil is an abstract strategy game that takes 2-4 players to the world of Scandinavian mythology and its many capricious gods. Thor, Odin, Frigg and Loki are reborn to impose their will within the nine worlds. Yggdrasil, the tree of Odin, is the force that keeps this fragile system functioning. The players must manipulate the runic stones in order to gain the most points and thus win the game.

Listed in American Games #4162. 1977, Advertising, Comics, Board Game.

The object of the game is to win by becoming Senior VP Media first. Career points are acquired to reach the goal. Each of the number of job levels has 6 points. The job levels are Rookie Buyer, Assistant Buyer, Buyer, Buyer Supervisor, Assoc Media Director, V.P. Media director and lastly the goal Senior VP Media.

The equipemnt is a board with 4 pawns for the players, 10 decks of cards, 2 dice, a "The Boss" sign, and four black pegs with a horseshoe shaped scoring track in the box bottom. Nine of the decks of cards are for the demographics categories, the tenth is for the "Challenge the Boss" deck. You can only challenge the boss when on a buy square. The board has an outside track for player movement.

Players get 2 experience points for passing "Start." They can gain or lose experince points when they "buy" demographic results on the board's nine different demographic categories based on age and sex. You can get "fired" and sent to the "Unemployemnt Office" sqaure on the board. You remain there until you get rehired by roll of 9 to 12 on the dice. You can become the boss by getting promoted. There are sqaures with special instructions for "Take a long lunch", "Leave briefcase in cab", and "Work Overtime."

Listed in American Games #4163. 1984, Music, Board Game.

A roll-and-move game in which players try to complete an 8-bar staff and song title by collecting notes and words. While there is education value in teaching recognition of music notation and theory, the game's mechanics have little to do with music.

From the Manufacturer's instructions: 
"No musical knowledge required. Just read, count, and roll dice."

"A game of chance by rolling the dice. Each player will encircle board several times in one game. Player keeps moving his token around the board the number of spaces indicated by the total sum of the two dice. Each space landed upon and each card drawn directs the movements of teh player. No one is safe even in his own play area. He must follow directions of space landings. There is no blocking, no bumping players off spaces and no back obligations. First player to fill his staff with notes and complete a song title is the winner. It can be very frustrating at times with continual gains and losses; such as real composers go through as they create a song. A player who has the least notes or words during the game can be the winner at the last minute though it appears he is losing."

"Object of Game: A player must fill his 8 BAR STAFF with 4 beats to each measure containing the right amount of notes and complete a SONG TITLE of four words or more which say something."

"EQUIPMENT: Board with indicated play spaces, four 8 bar staffs, four tokens to represent each composer, two dice, 500 words, 50 whole notes (clear discs) 50 half notes (white discs) 75 quarter notes (black discs) and 75 Directional cards."

Listed in American Games #4165. 1980, Sports, Baseball, Board Game.

Listed in American Games, #4172. 1940s, Travel, Air, Board game.

Three Point Landing -- Race your planes through all their destinations -- Here’s a thrilling game Full of sensations

Three Point Landing consists of a play board illustrated with a map of the United States and part of Canada, 24 destination cards, a spinner and wooden figures representing airplanes, (in the deluxe edition the map on the play board also includes Central and South America, and 36 instead of 24 destination cards.

Advance Games Corp, N.Y.C.
No.242 1942 Made in USA

Directions for Playing
Distribute the destination cards equally among all the players. Each player is also given a figure which represents his aeroplane. The object of “THREE POINT LANDING” is to cover all cities listed on your destination cards and then return to the starting place, namely “LaGuardia Field” New York City, before your opponents. Whoever returns first is the winner, before beginning study your route cards, and the map to determine the shortest round trip route, and arrange your cards accordingly. The players spin the dial in turn, and moves along the desired route, advancing the same amount of spaces as the spin. He must land on every city listed on the cards even though he spins a greater number. (Example: if he is three spaces from one of his cities and spins a six he still only advances three spaces to the city and then waits his next turn.) If a stop is made at a space with a “FORCED LANDING” or a “MOTOR REPAIRING” picture - ---in red clolor---the player must return to the last numbered town, it is necessary to spin the exact number of spaces to LaGuardia Field, New York City in order to land there at the finish. (Example: if there are three spaces left to the field, a three must be spun in order to land there.) The cities on the map have numbers that correspond to the numbers on the destination cards, so that small children will have no difficulty in identifying the position of the cities on the map.

Listed in American Games, #4175. 1976, Military, Board Game.

A typical move-and-capture game, such as Draugths or Checkers. The board represents a castle and a perimeter. Players move along paths that connect spaces together. Capture is by jumping over an adjacent piece to any vacant space beyond and is mandatory. Both players have the same pieces - one King, four Knights and eight pawns. The pieces have a hierarchy where a piece may not capture a more important piece.

One player is the Defender and the other the Attacker. The Defender starts his pieces from the middle of the board whilst the attacker starts on the perimeter. The object is to make the other player resign by eliminating enough pieces that there is no point in continuing.

The rules are extensive with many elaborations, hints and examples of play.

name.value: Baseball: The Game for Young America

item.description:
An early card driven pitch-by-pitch baseball simulation designed for two players.

Game Contents: Playing Board, Deck of 36 Baseball Cards, 4 Wooden Markers for Batter and Base Runners, 2 Wooden Markers for Strikes and Balls, 1 Wooden Marker for Outs, 1 Wooden Marker for Runs Scored in an Inning, Score Sheet, Instructions.

To play, the cards are shuffled and held in the hand of the player at bat. The player in the field calls a pitch (fastball, curve, slow ball, drop, or knuckle ball). The result of the pitch is read from the top card. Pitch results include strike, ball, foul ball, hit batsman, wild pitch, balk or "field play."

When "field play" is the result of the pitch, the card is turned over to the Field Play side to determine the play outcome. Different play outcomes are included on each card, and the specific outcome used is based upon the number of outs and the number and location of baserunners.

After the result for a particular pitch has been determined, that card is discarded and play continues with the next card in the deck.

Although the game concept is simple, it works quite well, and play can be very competitive. However, the strategic aspects of baseball are ignored. There is no bunting, hit and run, positioning of the defense, etc.

This game has one notable oddity. The game board is a depiction of a baseball field with defenders drawn at the normal defensive positions. The defenders are numbered based upon standard baseball scoring conventions, except that the corner outfielders are reversed--that is, the rightfielder is shown as "7" and the leftfielder as "9."

This game was produced and marketed for at least 10 years under a variety of names: "Baseball", "Baseball Game for Young America", and "Little League Baseball".

item.description: Listed in American Games, #4183. Circa 1950s, Western, Board Game. Object of game: the object of the game is to move along the game board. In some cases this requires doing it 2 or three times while trying to acquire 5 feather cards. At the beginning of the game the first 8 spaces have actual Indian sign languages and you have to learn those signs to proceed along with the game. Whoever takes 5 large feather cards wins by becoming BIG CHIEF. This game looks as if it was re-done with somewhat similar if not easier rules in the mid 1960's under the name Little Chief

From the Box:

"It's fun to see the Circus. It's more fun to be a part of the Circus. This game of mine takes you into circus life. You can follow the track around the 3 rungs with the Clowns and the Ringmaster. You can build the various circus acts - the animal acts, the trapeze acts, the tumblers, the jugglers and others. There's a prize for each act you complete and whoever gets the most prizes, wins. Let's play!"

This game uses a simplistic card drawing and set collection method to move players around the board. Movement around the board seems to serve no purpose other than to kill time, as all the game mechanic is from drawing cards and placing cards on the game board to make sets. Points are accumulated when sets are completed, or when indicated by the type of card drawn at the beginning of the player's turn.

OBJECT
The object of the game is to win the most Emmett Kelly Prize Disks. A Prize is won when a player 

 Plays a Circus Act Card that completes and Act.
 Draws an Emmett Kelly Prize Card
 Stops on an Emmett Kelly space in the game board track.
 




SETUP
Place the Emmett Kelly Prize Disks in a pile to one side.

Mix up the action cards and place them face down in a pile near the game board

All players select a colored Playing Piece and place it on the matching Ringmaster space on the board. the player that chose Green goes first and then play proceeds to the left

Each turn starts by drawing an Action Card from the face down pile.

ACTION CARDS - WHAT THEY MEAN
Circus Act Cards. Each Circus Act card has a picture matching a part of an Act in the Circus, menagerie or Side Show. When Drawn, the player looks on the board for part of an Act it matches and places the card on it. The player also moves the playing piece the number of spaces shown on the card. moves are always in a clockwise direction.
Whenever a player draws and plays an Act Card that completes an Act, he takes one Emmett Kelly Prize Disk.

Emmett Kelly Cards. When drawn, the player moves ahead to the next Emmett Kelly space on the game board track and takes one Emmett Kelly Prize Disk.

Blue Clown Cards. When drawn, the player moves his playing piece the number of spaces shown on the card.

Red Clown Cards. When drawn, the player moves his playing piece the number of spaces shown in the card. Also if any player (whether the one drawing the Red Clown Card or not) has more Prizes than the others, that player returns one Prize to the Prize pile. If two or more players are tied for most Prizes, none is given up.

Ringmaster Cards. When drawn, the player moves to the next Ringmaster space and takes another turn.

Clown Dog Card. When drawn, the player moves to the next Clown Dog space and loses his next turn.

The Circus Act Cards are played on the board. All the other Action Cards are piled face up to one side after they are drawn and used.

WINNING
When all the Acts on the game board have been completed, by covering them with matching cards, the player with the most Emmett Kelly Prizes is the winner.

item.description:
Listed in American Games, #4186. 1946, Sports, Football, Board game.

This two-player football game featured a folding game board (football field), 36 play cards, a metal football, a first down marker, and wooden markers to track the down, quarter, and score.

Play begins with the play cards shuffled and placed face down on the board. The player on offense calls a play from a limited menu (long pass, short pass, end run, line buck, punt, field goal), and the top card is then turned over to determine the result of the play.

There is a good variety of play outcomes, including fumbles, intercepted passes, and penalties. However, the game was designed in an era when single wing formations dominated, passing was relatively rare, and offenses were often "three yards and a cloud of dust." As a result, long advances from scrimmage are rare. The longest possible gain is 41 yards on a long pass.

Defense does not come into play, and the player on defense simply must hope that the player on offense fails to achieve successful play outcomes.

One pass through the card deck constitutes a quarter of football.

This game might have nostalgic value for those who played it as youngsters, but there are far better football games available today.

name.value: Jace Pearson's Tales of the Texas Rangers

item.description: Based on "Tales of the Texas Rangers," a western adventure old-time radio drama that aired on the NBC radio network from 1950-1952, starring Joal McCrea and directed by Stacey Keach, Sr. The series was adapted for television and aired in the late 1950's, starring Willard Parker.

with art based off of Peter Rabbit.

As per the box lid, Pot O'Gold is the "Fortune Telling Game for 2-4 players, young or old".

This is a spin-and-move game similar to The Game of Life. Players spin and move 1 to 6 spaces, following the game track where they will encounter a variety of Lucky and Unlucky events, including finding their "Future Husband or Wife", along the way.

The goal is to reach the Finish Line and "Win A Pile Of Lucky Pieces".

Spaceship is a spin and move space exploration game published by All Fair Games about 1948 (estimated on knowledge of the Jet age in 1944 -45 (i.e V2 Rocket) and appearance of flying saucers in 1947). Retro graphics adorn the board with characters like the Saturn Saucerman, Mars Batman and Giant Robot Space Master. Players travel from Terra (Earth)via Saturn and Luna (the moon) to the Zero Gravity Space Station. From there players continue via Mars or Venus to Jupiter. The pathway that players travel along is called "Spaceways". The Spaceways are under the control of the Interplanet Patrol System of United Planets. Each spaceship has a Cosmic Space-o-gram receiving set and when a player lands on a space marked "Take Space-o-gram", the player takes a Space-o-gram Card and follows the instructions. 
All ships must stop at the "Zero Gravity Space Station" and when leaving if a player spins an even number they go to Jupiter via Venus, and an odd number via Mars to Jupiter. Players cannot stop on the Asteroids as the nears Jupiter but spin a larger enough number to carry across the Asteroids. 
The First to reach Jupiter wins. Listed in[American Games] #4195.

Space Mouse was a character on the Woody Woodpecker cartoon television show.

This game comes with a playing board consisting of a map of the 48 states, 48 different liscense plates, one from each state, 4 car pieces and a die. Object of the game is to roll the die and try to pick up as many plates as you can. Player who gets the most plates wins the game

Listed in American Games.


 4197. 1945, Hand with money cover. Sports, Horseracing, Board game



 4198. 1945, Man in polka dot suit cover. Sports, Horseracing, Board game



 4199. 1945, Three players with money cover. Sports, Horseracing, Board game


Game based on the famous Sweepstakes race run in Ireland. The object of the game is to,of course, win the Sweepstakes Race.

The game comes with 1 die, 4 colored horses with wooden stands, 25 colored markers and 1000 dollars [NOTE: Unknown how many colored cardboard markers and how much money present indicates a complete game. My copy came with a sheet of 27 (9x3) brown markers in addition to 25 already cut-out markers - were 2 sheets of each color provided? Additionally the rules state that each player starts with $1,900 (not $1,000) broken out into 16 $100 bills, 4 $50 bills and 20 $5 bills, meaning there should be at least 64 $100 bills, 16 $50 bills and 80 $5 bills in a complete set, maybe more]. Players move around the board contributing money into the Sweepstakes purse. buying horses, and buying sweepstakes tickets.

If a player lands on a square already owned by another player, the player makes a side bet of 5.00 by paying the fee to the owner of the horse. If that horse eventually wins the owner must pay off the bettor at odds shown below the name and price of his horse.

A player must be on the yellow circuit of the board in order to win. If a roll puts his marker past the "winning post" square on his first time around he must go around the circuit once more. As he hears the 'Winning Post" position a 2nd time he must stop if a roll were to take him past the square and then on another turn re-roll and try again to hit the Winning Post square by exact roll. If he does he takes all the money in the Sweeps Fund, pays off all bets on his horse and then wins the game.
